'''Joseph Amos Milburn, Jr.''' (April 1, 1927 – January 3, 1980) was an [[African-American]] [[rhythm and blues]] [[singer]] and [[pianist]],<ref name="Music">{{cite book
| first= Paul
| last= Du Noyer
| year= 2003
| title= The Illustrated Encyclopedia of Music
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Flame Tree Publishing 
| location= Fulham, London
| isbn= 1-904041-96-5
| page= 181}}</ref> popular during the 1940s and 1950s. He was born and died in [[Houston]], [[Texas]].

One commentator noted, "Milburn excelled at good-natured, upbeat romps about booze and partying, imbued with a vibrant sense of humour and double entendre, as well as vivid, down-home imagery in his lyrics."<ref name="Music">{{cite book
| first= Paul
| last= Du Noyer
| year= 2003
| title= The Illustrated Encyclopedia of Music
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Flame Tree Publishing 
| location= Fulham, London
| isbn= 1-904041-96-5
| page= 166}}</ref>

==Life and career==
Born in Houston, one of thirteen children, by the age of five years Milburn was playing tunes by piano. He enlisted in the [[United States Navy]] when he was fifteen and earned thirteen [[Service star|battle stars]] in the [[Philippines]], before returning to Houston and organizing a sixteen-piece [[band (music)|band]] playing in Houston [[nightclub|clubs]] and was Managed by William & Geneva Church. Milburn participated with the Houston [[jazz]] and [[blues]] musicians. He was a polished pianist and performer and during 1946 attracted the attention of a woman who arranged a [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] session with [[Aladdin Records (US)|Aladdin Records]] in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]]. Milburn's relationship with Aladdin lasted eight years during which he produced more than 75 [[song|sides]]. His cover version of "[[Down the Road a Piece]]" (1946) was a [[blues]] song with a [[Texas]] [[boogie]] beat that was similar in many respects to [[rock music]].<ref name="roll">{{cite book
| first=& James Henke (eds) 
| last= Anthony DeCurtis
| year=1980 
| title= The RollingStone: The Definitive History of the Most Important Artists and Their Music
| edition=(3rd Ed.) 
| publisher=Random House, Inc. 
| location=New York, N.Y.
| pages= 9
| isbn= 0-679-73728-6}}</ref> However, none became popular until 1949 when seven of his [[Single (music)|singles]] got the attention of the [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]] audience.  "Hold Me Baby" and "[[Chicken Shack Boogie]]" landed numbers eight and nine on ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'''s survey of 1949's R&B [[Bestseller (music)|Bestseller]]s.<ref name="shaw">{{cite book
| first= Arnold
| last= Shaw
| year= 1978
| title= Honkers and Shouters
| edition= 
| publisher=Macmillan Publishing Company 
| location= New York
| pages= 99–101
| isbn= 0-02-061740-2}}</ref>
He became one of the main performers  associated with the [[Central Avenue, Los Angeles, California|Central Avenue]] music scene in Los Angeles. He was also a popular touring artist, and won awards from both ''[[Down Beat]]'' magazine (Best Blues and Jazz Star) and ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' magazine (Top R&B Artist).<ref name="Kelly">{{cite web
  | last = Kelly
  | first = Red
  | title = Amos Milburn - Christmas (Comes But Once A Year) (KING 5405)
  | work = The B Side
  | date = December 19, 2005
  | url = http://redkelly.blogspot.com/2005/12/amos-milburn-christmas-comes-but-once.html
  | accessdate = April 2, 2010}}</ref> Among his best-known [[song]]s was "[[One Bourbon, One Scotch, One Beer|One Scotch, One Bourbon, One Beer]]". During 1950 Milburn's "Bad, Bad, Whiskey" scored the top of the R&B [[record chart]] and began a series of drinking songs (none [[songwriter|written]] by Milburn, but several composed by [[Rudy Toombs]]). However, there is not any evidence that Milburn had an alcohol problem.<ref name="russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray
| edition= 
| publisher= Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| pages= 145–146
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref>

Milburn continued his successful drinking songs through 1952 ("Thinking and Drinking", "Trouble in Mind") and was by now touring the country playing clubs.  While touring the [[Midwestern United States|Midwest]] that summer, he announced that he would disband his [[combo]] team and continue as a [[solo (music)|solo]] act and that autumn he joined [[Charles Brown (musician)|Charles Brown]] for a [[Southern United States|Southern]] [[concert|concert tour]]. For the next few years each of his tours was composed of a series of one-nighters. After three years of solo performing he returned to Houston during 1956 to reform his band. During 1957 Milburn's releases with Aladdin Records did not sell well, and the [[record label]], having its own problems, terminated. He tried to regain commercial success with a few more releases with [[Ace Records (US)|Ace Records]] but his time had passed. [[Airplay (radio)|Radio airplay]] was emphasizing on the teenage market.<ref name="tnt">{{cite web
|url=http://home.earthlink.net/~jaymar41/amos.html
|title=Amos Milburn-Texas TNT ©1999JCMarion
|publisher=
|accessdate=2006-11-05 
}}</ref>

Milburn contributed to the R&B Yuletide [[canon (music)|canon]] twice.  The first was in 1949, with "Let's Make Christmas Merry, Baby", on Aladdin Records, and then again during 1960 with "Christmas (Comes but Once a Year)" for [[King Records (USA)|King Records]]. The song appeared as the [[A-side and B-side|b-side]] of Brown's holiday classic "[[Please Come Home for Christmas]]".<ref name="Kelly" /><ref name="amg">{{cite web
|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p460/biography|pure_url=yes}}
|title=Amos Milburn Biography
|publisher=allmusic
|accessdate=2006-11-06 
}}</ref>

Milburn's final [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] was for an [[album]] by [[Johnny Otis]]. This was during 1972 after he had been incapacitated by a [[stroke]], so much so that Otis had to play the left-hand piano parts for his enfeebled old friend.<ref name="russell"/> His second stroke resulted in [[amputation]] of a leg because of circulatory problems. He died soon after at the age of 52 years from a third stroke.<ref name="amg"/>

==Legacy==
The [[Texas|Texan]] boogie-woogie pianist and singer was an important performer of blues music during the years immediately after [[World War II]].<ref name="palmer">{{cite book
| first= Robert
| last= Palmer
| year=1982 
| title=Deep Blues 
| edition= 
| publisher=Penguin Books 
| location=United States
| pages = 223 
| isbn= 0-14-006223-8}}</ref> 
Milburn was one of the first performers to switch from sophisticated jazz [[arrangement]]s to a louder "jump" blues. He began to emphasize [[rhythm]] and technical qualities of [[human voice|voice]] and instrumentation second.<ref name="gillett">{{cite book
| first=Charlie 
| last=Gillett  
| year= 1996
| title= The Rise of Rock and Roll
| edition= 2nd
| publisher= Da Capo Press
| location=New York, N.Y.
| pages= 135
| isbn= 0-306-80683-5}}</ref>
His energetic songs, about getting "high", were admired by fellow musicians, such as [[Little Willie Littlefield]], [[Floyd Dixon]] and his prime disciple, [[Fats Domino]].<ref name="russell"/>

He was a commercial success for eleven years and influenced many [[musician|performers]].  Fats Domino credited Milburn consistently as an influence on his music.<ref name="tnt"/>

==Discography==
===Selected recordings===
* "Amos Blues" - 1946
* "[[Down the Road a Piece]]" - 1947
* "[[Chicken Shack Boogie]]" - 1948
* "A&M Blues" - 1948
* "[[Bewildered]]" - 1948
* "Hold Me, Baby" - 1949
* "In the Middle of the Night" - 1949
* "Roomin' House Boogie" - 1949
* "Let’s Make Christmas Merry, Baby" - 1949
* "Bad, Bad, Whiskey" - 1950
* "Thinkin' And Drinkin" - 1952 - written by [[Rudy Toombs]]
* "[[Trouble in Mind (song)|Trouble in Mind]]" - 1952
* "Let Me Go Home, Whiskey"<ref name=pc2>{{Gilliland |url=http://digital.library.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metadc19746/m1/ |title=Show 2 - Play A Simple Melody: An introduction to rhythm & blues }}</ref> - 1953 - written by [[Shifty Henry]]
* "[[One Bourbon, One Scotch, One Beer|One Scotch, One Bourbon, One Beer]]" - 1953 - also written by Rudy Toombs
* ''Rockin' The Boogie'' - ([[Gramophone record|10-inch LP]]) - 1955

===LPs===
* ''Let's Have A Party'' - 1957 - [[Score Records]]
* ''A Million Sellers'' -  1962 - [[Imperial Records]]
* ''The Return Of The Blues Boss'' - 1963 - [[Motown Records]]

===Compilation albums===
* ''The Best of Amos Milburn: Down the Road Apiece'' - ([[Compact disc|CD]] - 1994 - [[EMI America Records]]
* ''The Complete Aladdin Recordings of Amos Milburn'' - (CD [[box set]]) - 1994 - [[Mosaic Records]]
* ''Blues, Barrelhouse & Boogie Woogie'' - (CD box set) - 1996 - [[Capitol Records]]<ref name="russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray
| edition= 
| publisher= Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| pages= 146
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref>
* ''The Best of Amos Milburn'' - (CD) - 2001 - [[EMI-Capitol Special Markets]]
* ''The Original Sound Of Charles Brown & Amos Milburn{with Jackie Shane-Bob Marshall & The Crystals}''Lp 1955? On Pickwick/Grand Prix Series, Pickwick International Inc.
